entry.title: ROSEBURG HAS HOTTEST DAY OF THE YEAR ON FRIDAY
entry.summary: May 31, 2025 6:00 a.m. Friday was the hottest day of the year so far in Roseburg. Forecasters at the National Weather Service in Medford told News Radio 93-9 FM and 1240 KQEN that the mercury reached 91 degrees at the Roseburg Regional Airport. The previous hottest days for 2025 were May 26th and May...

entry.summary: May 30, 2025 3:00 p.m. On Friday, Governor Tina Kotek formally requested Presidential Disaster Declarations to provide federal support for flood recovery in communities devastated by the 2025 floods across Coos, Curry, Douglas, and Harney counties. entry.title: Celebrate summer solstace at a stargazing party
entry.summary: Bright Jupiter rapidly slips into the sun’s glare as Mercury slowly climbs into view. If you have a nearly perfect west-northwest horizon or an ocean view, you may be able to spot Jupiter over the next week.

entry.title: Accreditation matters: Wildlife Safari steps up amid game park crisis
entry.summary: WINSTON — Zoos give ticket holders a front row seat to the wild. What isn’t covered with the fair however is the complex web of factors maintaining the organization — from financials to conservation, there’s more beyond the enclosures.

entry.title: Roseburg Set to See Hottest Day of 2025 So Far Today
entry.summary: Roseburg is expected to hit near 90 degrees Friday - making it the hottest day of 2025 so far. The National Weather Service says highs will be 15 - 20 degrees above normal. A gradual cooldown is expected over the weekend.

entry.title: Unstoppable: The Class of 2025
entry.summary: If you’ve driven north of exit 129 lately, you’ve seen it: Umpqua Community College’s bold new billboard, featuring a proud Riverhawk graduate and a single word -“Unstoppable.” That’s not just a slogan. It’s a mindset. It’s a promise we make…

entry.title: Beloved Longtime Voice of Douglas County Retires After 34 Years of Service
entry.summary: Dawna Zarbano, a trusted voice in Douglas County for 22 years, retired today after 34 years of service. Known to first responders and the public alike, she signed off with a heartfelt final message, closing a remarkable career in emergency communications.
